parts:
It was quite the trip here from Boracay. We ended up catching a van in the morning at 5:00 a.m. to the port from the park. We took the ferry or a little bolt over to the airport area. And technically we got into another van to get to the airport. Just a short drive away, then caught a flight to Cebu, then layover in Cebu. We hung out in the lounge. I was able to use my priority pass to have both me and Walter there. We ate a bunch of food and just hung out. I ended up napping on one of the benches that they had. Since last night I just partied my ass off and went directly to the the pickup at 5:00 a.m. I didn't sleep at all so I caught up on sleep at the lounge. Probably slept 2 hours or so. We had a 4-Hour layover in Cebu. From there another airplane to the Siargao airport which is super tiny. And then another van to the house. 

We arrived at the house. It was supposed to be a two bedroom two bathroom but it actually just has the one bedroom so Wouter went looking for a hotel nearby. 

Meanwhile, I'm on a mission to go back to my favorite smoothie spot and then rent a scooter and meet up with him afterwards.

I'm staying in the same house that I stayed in before.  That's right on the ocean front. The last time I was on the second floor this time I'm on the first floor and I'm loving it. Already settling in the space. This morning I went and dropped off the laundry. Should be ready by 7:00 p.m.  Then I went to the local market. Bought some fish, shrimp, eggs, oil, bananas and mangoes. Then I came back to the house, made some of the eggs for breakfast and then I went out to eat on the balcony and it's an open area. It opens up straight to the ocean. And a few kids swam up from the ocean to say hi and ask if they can shower and they wanted some food. So I went in and got them some bananas and I cut them up some mango. And just enjoyed having breakfast together

# üü§ TWO-PAGE FOLD ‚Äî **Island French Press Coffee (Paul‚Äôs Cooking Show)**  
**Thursday ¬∑ Jan 22 ¬∑ Rain Day ¬∑ Oceanfront Kitchen**

## ‚úÖ PAGE 1 (LEFT) ‚Äî ‚ÄúTHE SETUP‚Äù (use these photos)
**Photo A (top-left):** grounds in the cup (your first pic)  
**Photo B (top-right):** empty press with coffee already inside (your second pic)  
**Photo C (bottom-left):** plunger assembly standing up (your third pic)  
**Photo D (bottom-right):** mug on the flame heating water (your fourth pic)

### Title (big):
**ISLAND FRENCH PRESS COFFEE**

### Subtitle:
**No kettle. No waste. Just what you need.**

### Caption blocks (match to photos):
**A ‚Äî Grind / Grounds**  
> I‚Äôm using what I‚Äôve got: coffee, a cup, and island efficiency.  
> Aim for a **coarse grind** (like sea salt). Too fine = gritty, bitter.

**B ‚Äî Press Ready**  
> French press = simple physics. Coffee + water + time.  
> The magic is controlling **ratio, temp, and steep time**.

**C ‚Äî The Plunger**  
> Don‚Äôt press yet. Let the coffee **steep first**.  
> Pressing early makes it weak. Pressing hard makes it muddy.

**D ‚Äî Island Water Hack (no kettle)**  
> Heat a **small amount of water** directly in a mug on the flame.  
> **Low flame + thick glass** = controlled heat.  
> (If the glass feels thin, use a small pot instead.)

---

## ‚úÖ PAGE 2 (RIGHT) ‚Äî ‚ÄúSTEP-BY-STEP HOW-TO‚Äù (full instructions)

### 1) Measure (keep it simple)
**Best everyday ratio:**  
- **1 heaping tablespoon per ~200 ml** water (one big mug)  
OR  
- **1:15 ratio** (ex: 20g coffee to 300g water)

**Island rule:**  
> If you want it stronger, add coffee first ‚Äî not more steep time.

---

### 2) Heat the water (your mug-on-flame method)
- Use a **low flame**.
- Heat until you see **tiny bubbles forming** and steam rising.
- Ideal range is **just below boiling** (hot but not rolling).

**Island reality check:**  
> If you boil it hard, let it sit **30‚Äì60 seconds** before pouring so it doesn‚Äôt scorch the grounds.

---

### 3) Pre-warm the press (optional, but pro)
If you have extra hot water:
- Pour a splash into the press, swirl, dump.

Why:  
> Warm glass = stable temperature = better extraction.

---

### 4) Add coffee to the press
- Add your grounds (Photo A energy).
- Level it out by tapping the press lightly.

---

### 5) Bloom (this is the ‚Äúchef move‚Äù)
- Pour **just enough water to wet all the grounds** (about 2‚Äì3x the amount of coffee).
- Stir gently (or swirl).
- Wait **30 seconds**.

Why it matters:  
> Bloom releases gas and makes the brew smoother and more even.

---

### 6) Fill + steep
- Pour the rest of your hot water in slowly.
- Stop about **1‚Äì2 cm from the top** (don‚Äôt overflow).
- Put the lid/plunger on top **but don‚Äôt press**.
- Steep for **4 minutes**.

**Timing guide:**
- **3:30** = lighter / brighter  
- **4:00** = balanced (my default)  
- **4:30‚Äì5:00** = stronger, but can go bitter if grind is fine

---

### 7) Press (slow = clean)
- Press **slowly** over **15‚Äì25 seconds**.
- Use gentle steady pressure.
- If it fights you hard: grind is too fine.

**Key rule:**  
> Don‚Äôt slam the press. That churns the grounds and makes it gritty.

---

### 8) Serve immediately (important)
- Pour into your mug right away (your ‚Äúcoffee victory‚Äù shot).
- Don‚Äôt leave it sitting in the press.

Why:  
> Coffee left in contact with grounds keeps extracting and turns bitter.

---

### 9) Taste + adjust next time (fast troubleshooting)
**Too weak?**  
- Add more coffee (or grind slightly finer)

**Too bitter / harsh?**  
- Water too hot OR steep too long OR grind too fine

**Too gritty / muddy?**  
- Grind too fine OR you pressed too hard/fast  
- Let it sit 30 seconds after pressing before pouring

---

### 10) Cleanup (island easy mode)
- Knock grounds into trash/compost (or outside if that‚Äôs the setup)
- Rinse mesh filter
- Air dry the plunger assembly

---

---

## **JANUARY 26 ‚Äî FINAL HOURS IN SIARGAO**

**Coin Toss Day. No rewind button.**

Late start. Deep recovery sleep finally caught up with me.  
Slow morning energy, clear head. The kind of day that feels like it‚Äôs asking a question instead of giving answers.

Packed most of my things.  
Left the luggage at the hotel ‚Äî freedom mode activated.

### **The Decision Point**
Four hours until departure.  
Two possible endings.

- **Heads:** ride north, chase Little Hawaii, squeeze every last drop out of the island.  
- **Tails:** stay grounded ‚Äî gym, food, calm goodbye.

No physical coin.  
So I did what modern travelers do.

**Google ‚Üí ‚Äúflip a coin.‚Äù**

**Result: Tails.**

### **Tails Means Grounded**
Instead of chasing distance, I chose presence.

Hit the gym first ‚Äî not the plan, but the right move.  
Sweat, mirrors, foam rollers, quiet focus.  
Body felt heavy but honest.

*(Bike return still pending ‚Äî this was the detour, not the conclusion.)*

### **Fuel Stop**
Post-gym meal.  
Simple food, no rush.  
One last slow sit before logistics take over.

### **Checkpoint Update**
**3:57 PM ‚Äî Siargao Airport**

- Luggage checked.  
- Island officially released.  
- Now eating at the airport restaurant, watching time compress again.

### **New Question (Unlocked)**
Do I:
- Store my bags in Manila,
- Skip the hotel,
- Go straight into the night,
- Then loop back to the airport?

Undecided.  
But that‚Äôs tomorrow‚Äôs page.

**Siargao chapter: closed.**  
Not with a sprint ‚Äî but with intention.

## **SIARGAO ‚Äî ARC COMPLETE**

Not a dramatic exit.  
No big finale.  
Just the right moment to leave.

Siargao gave me exactly what I needed this time:
- Slow mornings  
- Consistent movement  
- Surf attempts (and reality checks)  
- Gym rhythm  
- Clean food  
- Space to breathe  
- Time without urgency  

I didn‚Äôt conquer the island.  
I synced with it.

This wasn‚Äôt a place to rush through ‚Äî it was a place to **reset the system**.  
And the reset worked.

As of now, this chapter is closed.  
No return planned until **October / November** ‚Äî different season, different version of me.

Same island.  
New context.

**Siargao Arc: officially complete.** üå¥

---

## **FINAL DAY ‚Äî SIARGAO**

No dramatic send-off.  
Just momentum, one clean decision after another.

The coin toss was still pending ‚Äî but my body already chose.  
I ended up at the gym first.  
Last workout. Last sweat. Closing the loop.

From there, everything clicked into place:

- Dropped off the scooter ‚Äî no ceremony, just gratitude  
- The owner gave me a lift to **Shaka**  
- Ate one last meal there with **Maria** ‚Äî easy, familiar, unforced  
- Tuk-tuk back through town, island air rushing in  
- Picked up the laundry on the way  
- Packed everything up  
- Showered one last time at the hotel lobby  

And that was it.

No scrambling.  
No regret.  
No ‚Äúone more thing.‚Äù

Airport by **3:57 PM**.  
Luggage checked.  
Food in front of me.  
Smile still there.

Siargao didn‚Äôt end with a bang ‚Äî  
it ended **complete**.

Some places are for escape.  
Some are for indulgence.  
Siargao this time was for **alignment**.

I‚Äôm probably not back until **October / November**.  
Different season.  
Different pace.  
Different version of me.

Same island.

**Siargao Arc ‚Äî officially closed.** üå∫

parts:
Yes ‚Äî you **can store luggage around Manila Airport**, but the options vary depending on where you are and which terminal you‚Äôre at:

### üß≥ **Official airport storage**
**Luggage & More** at **NAIA Terminal 3 (T3)**  
- Secure left-luggage facility right inside **Terminal 3** arrivals.  
- They store bags behind counters with **24-hour CCTV and staffed service**.  
- Charges are typically around **‚Ç±350 per day** for a bag, with shorter-hour options too. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search3ÓàÅ

*(Note: official storage exists mainly at T3 ‚Äî earlier reports of a Terminal 1 facility are mixed or outdated, and many travelers either go to T3 or use third-party services instead.) ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search7ÓàÅ*

---

### üß≥ **Third-party luggage storage near the airport**
If you want more flexibility (hourly or daily), there are local services near NAIA that offer easy storage + short-term access:  
- **Bounce / Vertoe / LuggageHero** locations near the airport and in **Pasay city** ‚Äî some even within ~10 min of the terminals. You drop off + pick up at a shop or hotel partner. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search2ÓàÇturn0search18ÓàÅ  
- Prices vary but many start around a few dollars per day or per hour.

These third-party spots are handy if the airport counter is closed, full, or if you leave and want to explore **Manila** or nearby areas without dragging bags around.

---

‚úÖ **Tips before you go**
- If you‚Äôre landing in **Terminal 1** and need storage, consider either:
  - Going to **Terminal 3‚Äôs storage** (inside NAIA), or  
  - Using a third-party option nearby. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search3ÓàÅ  
- **Book ahead online** if you‚Äôre using third-party storage ‚Äî it saves hassles on busy days. ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search2ÓàÅ  
- Always check **current hours** when you arrive ‚Äî airport facilities can change hours or pricing without notice.

---
